The most effective fire mitigation strategy is widely considered to be prescribed fires. However, accurately forecasting the potential air quality impact from these fires, a critical factor in determining their location and timing, remains a challenging problem at hourly to daily time scales. This paper proposes a novel integration of prescribed fire simulation with a spatio-temporal graph neural network-based PM 2.5 forecasting model. The experiments in this work focus on determining the optimal time for implementing prescribed fires in California and quantifying the potential air quality trade-offs involved in conducting more prescribed fires outside the fire season.

Introduction

Across many parts of the western United States, wildfire size, severity, and fire season length have increased due to climate change. Wildfires in the western United States have led to the largest daily mean PM2.5 concentrations observed by ground-based sensors in recent years. Exposure to PM 2.5 is responsible for 4.2 million premature deaths worldwide per year. In California, additional PM 2.5 emissions from extreme wildfires over the past eight years have reversed nearly two decades of decline in ambient PM 2.5 concentrations. Prescribed fires, or controlled burns, have been widely accepted as an effective land management tool and could potentially reduce the resulting smoke from future wildfires. Since air quality is a major public concern surrounding prescribed fires, land managers conducting these burns require access to robust, near real-time predictions of downwind air pollution to determine suitable locations and burn windows.

This paper introduces a graph neural network (GNN) model that incorporates satellite observations of fire behavior to forecast PM 2.5 emissions from ambient sources, observed fires, and simulated controlled burns. The GNN-based forecasting system can aid land managers in minimizing the PM 2.5 exposure of vulnerable populations during controlled burns and inform the public when proposing prescribed fires.

Related Work

Previous studies on the effect of prescribed fires used chemical transport models (CTMs) like the Community Multiscale Air Quality (CMAQ) and Goddard Earth Observing System Atmospheric Chemistry (GEOS-Chem) models to calculate the PM 2.5 impact of prescribed fires at different locations. While CTMs can model chemical processes in PM 2.5 transport, generating accurate predictions requires a large volume of information due to complex chemical interactions. Furthermore, the extensive calculations in CTMs make it challenging to explore a large range of parameters for simulating prescribed burns.

In air quality predictions, machine learning models have been shown to outperform CTMs in terms of accuracy and computational burden. While several past works use machine learning to forecast air quality, this research is the first to utilize machine learning to predict PM 2.5 concentrations from simulated prescribed fires. Our research builds upon the GNN machine learning model from Wang et al. (2020), which was used to forecast non-wildfire-influenced PM 2.5 pollution in China. In contrast, this work focuses on simulating the effect of prescribed fires and predicting fire-influenced PM 2.5 in California.

Methods

Our dataset consists of PM 2.5, meteorological, and fire data at an hourly resolution over five years (2017-2021). The PM 2.5 concentration data, collected from 112 air quality sensor locations in California, is retrieved from the California Air Resources Board and the Environmental Protection Agency. The data for the seven meteorological variables, including wind speed and direction, total precipitation, and air temperature, are retrieved from the ERA5 Reanalysis database. The full list of predictors is provided in Table 1. The fire radiative power (FRP) provides information about the fire intensity, and we use the Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) instrument on board the Suomi satellites to obtain the FRP at each fire location. To assess the impact of nearby fires at the location of a PM 2.5 monitor, we aggregate the FRP values of all active fires within radii of 25km, 50km, 100km, and 500km. We use inverse distance weighting (IDW) and wind-based weighting to emphasize the fires that would likely have a more substantial downwind effect on PM 2.5 concentrations.
